comments.commentBody: I have an idea: A company requiring workers to take their pay on a prepaid company card should be required by New York State to submit to an E-Verify immigration audit every year for every employee and contractor. Trust me, the employer will go back to paper checks.
What do you mean the Bush administration did not heed the maxim "you break it, you own it"?  Are you saying Obama did?  Obama was the architect of our departure.  How has he "owned" Iraq?

"You broke it, you own it." I think "owning it" was really a major objective of the neocons. Owning in the sense of a pliant, subservient banana oil republic.

The frustration was that ownership was never transferred. The Iraqis of one stripe or another were not going to put their country up for sale, no matter how many surges, spent nuclear rounds, bombs, checkpoints, and gulags the US offered.

Sadly, the Bush II administration did not heed Colin Powell's Pottery Barn maxim: "You broke it, you own it." Where Bush I stopped short of Baghdad during the Gulf War, Bush II invaded, destabilizing Iraq and the region.

I am skeptical that additional American troop commitments could have stabilized Iraq over the long run, much as I was skeptical that an Americsn presence in Afghanistan could unify that nation under a pro-U.S. regime. Both Iraq and Afganistan have precarious political histories and multiple ethnic and religious divisions. It is naive and dangerous to believe that America could tame these regions and install representative democracy over the barrel of a gun.

The nation-building prescribed by David Brooks is past its sell-by date.

I can enter googolplex in my calculator:

10^(10^99) or is that 10 googolplex? OK then
10^(10^99)*.1

but it doesn't like it when I hit enter.

OVERFLOW ERROR

That was a dire flop and a terrible call -- but if anyone's on the take it's Pletikosa. Perhaps that first goal was allowable, but no way he should have let the other two in. Two hands on the PK and still he lets it by? Absolute howler of a game from him.

As everyone so far has pointed out Brazil looked labored and unconvincing for most of the match. But Croatia look even worse. No goals of their own, poor central defense, embarrassingly awful keeper.

It's only the first match and perhaps we shouldn't take too much from it, even if it did validate pre-tournament criticisms of Brazil. The one thing we can take away we already knew -- the standard of refereeing in the game is dismal. One referee on the pitch cannot do it all.
It was Richard Nixon, not Ford, who committed the Saturday Night Massacre, in October, 1973.

Bobby Flay, a "real New Yorker" who trained at a real New York culinary school, became well known as a talented chef via his real New York restaurants Bolo & Mesa Grill long before he was a TV star.  Real New Yorkers who pay attention to food understand that among "TV chefs," if Bobby Flay opens a new place in Manhattan, it will most certainly be the "real" thing.

Richard:

Here's the actual report:

http://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/Tracking_cl...

Strong on graphics, good source of summary numbers for energy mix and short-term trends in the same.

Weak on long-term projections (mostly wishful thinking, belief in the power of edicts to transform society). Note how the direction of the short-term trends is opposite to the long-term projections!

Still believes in Carbon Capture & Storage.

I didn't see any rigorous assessment of economic ramifications or a breakdown of projected costs and/or savings inherent to the proposed energy transformation. Perhaps this is buried somewhere in the references, however. Doesn't instill confidence in the robustness of cost calculations.

The CleanTech industry would appear to be driven primarily by a need for continued mandates to ensure its short-term survival. Long-term economic sustainability would require a massive increase in the market price of energy, which would dramatically affect society (particularly the poorest). It would drive the near-poor into poverty (the opposite of current trends).

Completely absent is any assessment of the effect this could have on climate.

Kurt in Switzerland

Leapy,

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eddington_number

What we did under Bush was dead wrong. Americans and Iraqis have suffered for it, but to walk away from a mess that we created is immoral. The claim that "Americans are tired of war" is no doubt correct, but we must finish what we began.

Perhaps we really don't mean all of those claims about democracy.

Obama gets involved in Iraq.  Obama gets testy.  President Obama reminds the hopelessness approaching Iraq.  These are tough times and they need to handle matters gently.  Kurds are attacking the Sunnis.  Really cut down on these shenanigans.

commercial real estate is our business and
my comments were principally directed at Wells not Flay. but just so you'll know, our business IS commercial real estate and
we're in NYC every month servicing our portfolio. "being pushed (your choice of words)" means your establishment is not making enough money to remain at a particular location. enjoy Gato.

Ironically, the United States is also pulling apart along the religious lines as defined by the political right.  Anyone not a Christian is persona non grata along with anyone whose values follow a liberal line.  Our government has not been much more effective than Iraq's over the past few years of Republican "obstruction as primary policy."  Fortunately for us Canada and Mexico are a bit more stable than Syria and, of course, everyone and his uncle has a gun.
Even Bollywood films portray child servants and physical abuse (of servants, children and women, as well as brutal man-on-man aggression) as run-of-the-mill behavior.

I have seen some Bollywood movies where rape is portrayed as the most normal thing. From what my friends tell me films in India don't have ratings so a child grows up watching all those rape scenes. Is it any wonder that there are so many rapes in the country?

Eye-opening, and should be read by anyone whose only knowledge of Indian culture comes from Bollywood or similar films. I remember a chilling account by an acquaintance of the callousness of her Indian friend toward the plight of slum children: she told her driver to simply run over the annoying children as they were a nuisance and in her way. These Indians treat their pets better than their servants.

"Well it ain't Wendell Willkie!"

Are there any kids today who would know Wendell Willkie? Besides David Steinberg, I mean?
I'm ashamed to say I drew a blank on his name the other night when "Jeopardy!" required the 1940 Republican presidential candidate.  I knew Dewey wasn't until 1944, but stalled.

The Mets just ran out of gas in extra innings and so did my solve. I'm gonna have to sleep on this toughie. I did get 38d so this one's for you Jimbo:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0GuX0NEfxiw

I BID you goodnight,

Bru

Unfortunately, there is very little that can be done. It seems the Kurds in the region are the most stable but too much overt support leads to difficulty with Turkey. The substructure of the entire region was destroyed by the neocons. Not that they are unhappy, since it leads to a greater need for a large US military and makes US oil (and Saudi) infinitely more valuable per barrel. Chaney and Halliburton are still raking it in off of their war.

Sure, it was a disaster for the US as a nation but for their interests, it has likely been their greatest stroke! These days treason is called patriotism.

Over a decade ago, Cheney and his puppet President Bush rushed us into a war with a nation that had nothing to do with 9-11, with Cheney's Halliburton making a fortune on it. They unleashed a hellish cauldron, got rid of our buffer with Iran and cost America in blood and fortune. Now there's a real chance Al Queda forces will take over Iraq, and, emboldened, may try the same in Pakistan, with its cache of nuclear weapons. Bush and Cheney are war criminals, and Boehner should be tried for treason. Enough!

Spot on.

We saw it on Saturday and LOVED it; it's the best show we've seen there all year (we're members).  Not only did every single performer do a terrific job in their respective roles, but the storyline was very touching and it also had a lot of humor.
Korea and Somalia weren't our best hours, either.

My ticket cost $40.00, of which there were tons available before the review came out. You have to committ earlier to a short-run, big production value, big name, summer shakespeare show a little earlier then the NYT review publish date, in order to fullfill your budgetary needs.
Don't the Iraqis have their own war planes?

Lance, are you of an age to sign up?  If you can, you should definitely enlist and if not I hope you are ready willing and able to cough up the money for this war you are so anxious to have and which Bush et al. decided we wouldn't even  have to pay for!
I agree. I hope that donations are made.
Didn't the voters in Virginia just term-limit Rep. Cantor.  You don't need term limits, you need an electorate who care enough to inform themselves about the issues and vote.

The perfect example of "you break it, you bought it".  Bush, Cheney, et al, fouled this up so badly that it can't be fixed.  We cannot solve a religious war in the black hole that is Iraq.  The hawks may be screaming for intervention, but Obama should not take the bate.  Iraq is done.  Syria is done.  There is nothing we can do.  The Middle East is in chaos, no thanks to our adventurism.
